malis2mali.py - concatenate multiple alignments¶

Author:Andreas Heger
Release:$Id$
Date:April 02, 2014
Tags:Python

Purpose¶

concatenate multiple alignments into a single multiple alignment.

This script requires the following input:

  1. Multiple alignments

The multiple alignments can be given as separate files (option –pattern-mali contains a ‘%%s’) or in a single file.

  1. A list of components

This file maps sequence identifiers in the multiple alignment file(s) to multiple alignment identifiers. The format for this file is a tab separated table containing the following fields:

1  sequence     a sequence identifier

2  input_id     The id under which the alignment is found. This value
                        is substituted for the '%%s' in
                        --pattern-mali.

3 component_id  The component_id or multiple alignment identifier.
                This field is optional. If no third column is specified,
                the input_id is used.

Methods:

filter-variants

only keep variant columns in the multiple alignment. Set --width to 3 to test for variant codons. Gaps will be ignored.

Usage¶

Example:

python malis2mali.py --help

Type:

python malis2mali.py --help

for command line help.

Command line options¶

Usage: malis2mali.py [options]

Options:
  --version             show program's version number and exit
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --no-usage            output help without usage information
  -b PATTERN_COMPONENT, --pattern-component=PATTERN_COMPONENT
                        how to extract identifier of mali from component name.
  -c FILENAME_COMPONENTS, --filename-components=FILENAME_COMPONENTS
                        filename of components to choose for each multiple
                        alignment.
  -e PATTERN_FILTER, --pattern-filter=PATTERN_FILTER
                        pattern of how to extract filter from identifier.
  -i INPUT_FORMAT, --input-format=INPUT_FORMAT
                        input format of multiple alignment
  -o OUTPUT_FORMAT, --output-format=OUTPUT_FORMAT
                        output format of multiple alignment
  --filename-mask-regions=FILENAME_MASK_REGIONS
                        mask regions given file. Input format is component_id
                        start   end with coordinates in
                        the multiple alignment.
  --filename-extract-regions=FILENAME_EXTRACT_REGIONS
                        extract regions given file. Input format is
                        component_id        start   end with coordinates in
                        the multiple alignment. The alignment is restricted to
                        the given coordinates by masking everything else.
  --filename-annotate-regions=FILENAME_ANNOTATE_REGIONS
                        annotate regions given file. Input format is
                        component_id       start   end     label with
                        coordinates in
                        the multiple alignment. The label should be a single
                        letter. If the file is empty, the full alignment is
                        output with label N.
  --use-input-id        use input-id instead of component_id in
                        --filename-X-regions
  -a PATTERN_MALI, --pattern-mali=PATTERN_MALI
                        filename pattern for input multiple alignment files.
  --test=TEST           test output with first # components.
  --skip-doubles        skip doubles, takes first entry encountered.
  --ignore-missing      ignore missing alignments [False].
  --remove-all-gaps=REMOVE_ALL_GAPS
                        remove fully masked or gapped positions in a multiple
                        alignment. The integer parameter supplies the frame.
                        Use 3 for codon alignments.
  --remove-any-gaps=REMOVE_ANY_GAPS
                        remove positions in a multiple alignment containing at
                        least one gap. The integer parameter supplies the
                        frame. Use 3 for codon alignments.
  --sample=SAMPLE       sample # components.
  --sample-method=SAMPLE_METHOD
                        sampling method: without-replacement=sample without
                        replacement. length-sample: sample components of same
                        length (without replacement).
  --filename-sample-reference=FILENAME_SAMPLE_REFERENCE
                        filename to with reference components. The components
                        should be part of the file supplied by --filename-
                        components.
  --minimum-mali-length=MINIMUM_MALI_LENGTH
                        minimum multiple alignment length.
  --filename-coordinates=FILENAME_COORDINATES
                        filename of coordinates that constitute the multiple
                        alignment.
  --filename-identifiers=FILENAME_IDENTIFIERS
                        filename with list of identifiers to use.
  -x PATTERN_IDENTIFIER, --pattern-identifier=PATTERN_IDENTIFIER
                        pattern to extract identifier from a sequence header.
  -w WIDTH, --width=WIDTH
                        width of an alignment column (choose 3 for codon
                        alignments) [default=none].
  -m METHODS, --method=METHODS
                        methods to apply
  -p PARAMETERS, --parameters=PARAMETERS
                        parameter stack for methods that require one.
  --mask-acgtn          mask. Anything not [ACGTN] will be N.
  -v LOGLEVEL, --verbose=LOGLEVEL
                        loglevel [1]. The higher, the more output.
  --timeit=TIMEIT_FILE  store timeing information in file [none].
  --timeit-name=TIMEIT_NAME
                        name in timing file for this class of jobs [all].
  --timeit-header       add header for timing information [none].
  --random-seed=RANDOM_SEED
                        random seed to initialize number generator with
                        [none].
  -I FILE, --stdin=FILE
                        file to read stdin from [default = stdin].
  -L FILE, --log=FILE   file with logging information [default = stdout].
  -E FILE, --error=FILE
                        file with error information [default = stderr].
  -S FILE, --stdout=FILE
                        file where output is to go [default = stdout].
